awd_titl_txt: CyberTraining: Implementation: Small: Collaborative Research: Easy-Med: Interdisciplinary Training in Security, Privacy-Assured Internet of Medical Things
awd_abstract_narration:
The combination of a network of physical devices embedded with electronics, Internet connectivity, and other hardware, such as sensors, that can communicate and interact with others over the Internet is known as the Internet of Things.  One familiar application of this technology is the "smart home" in which people monitor and control their lights, thermostats and security systems remotely using smart phones or smart speakers. An Internet of Things-based framework for the healthcare industry is called the Internet of Medical Things.  This technology connects patients to their physicians and supports the transfer of medical data over the Internet.  Concerns about the privacy of data transmitted over the Internet and network security are challenges facing all applications of the Internet of Things concept, but they can be exacerbated by the knowledge gap between the designers of the frameworks and the end users in the medical field.  As the healthcare industry grows to meet the needs of an aging population, the workforce that designs Internet of Medical Things devices and the networks that connect them must be ready to address these privacy and security concerns. The project is addressing this gap, and thus serves the national interest, as stated by NSF's mission: to promote the progress of science; to advance the national health, prosperity and welfare.

Easy-Med is a multi-disciplinary training program designed to improve core literacy of cyber infrastructure for students at the undergraduate level in northeast Texas. The six-week-long mentored program provides immersive training to increase the students' ability to develop and use secure, privacy-assured sensing healthcare frameworks.  A different training module is provided each week and each day of the module includes four hours of lecture and three hours of hands-on lab exercises.  Training modules introduce the students to the different aspects involved in designing devices and networks for the Internet of Medical Things.  The six training modules, components of which are also provided online, include: 1) types of biosensors and Internet of Medical Things components, 2) system-level modeling of Internet of Medical Things networks, 3) signal and data analytics used in healthcare, 4) security and privacy assurance in Internet of Medical Things technology, 5) applications of biosensors in the healthcare industry, and 6) use of and ethics involved in using the Internet of Medical Things in the community setting.  Students who participate in Easy-Med during the summer are encouraged to further their knowledge and provide outreach about the program by participating in a Build-a-Thon activity during the following fall semester and a research symposium in the following spring semester.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to develop an off-the-shelf component-based medical training framework, Easy-Med, to train STEM students with sensing, security, and privacy aspects of smart healthcare and provide them with a career path in smart healthcare. The project provided opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science and engineering areas of Internet of Medical Things (IoMT). The key outcomes of this project include:

1. A novel, low-cost, voice-enabled Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) framework for real-time emotion detection.

2. A novel assistive framework that utilizes biosignals such as voice and physiological responses for continuous health monitoring and personalized feedback through haptics.

3. Novel methods for closing the feedback loop in smart healthcare frameworks by integrating soft and flexible sensors.

4. Novel assistive frameworks with embedded intelligence for emotion recognition, including anxiety monitoring, substance abuse detection, and suicidal ideation detection.

5. Novel low-power edge computing solutions for monitoring preterm infants using IoMT-based frameworks.

6. Machine learning methods for integrating IoMT into medical services and smart tourism.

7. Novel methods for developing application-specific wearable body-sensor networks for real-time analysis and feedback.

8. Easy-to-follow instructional materials for designing IoMT frameworks, covering deployment and data collection steps.

9. Active learning modules such as computational thinking, problem-based learning, and entrepreneurial modules into interdisciplinary topics related to IoMT design.

Formal dissemination is performed through 4 Master of Science in Electrical Engineering (MSEE) Theses, 26 peer-reviewed conference and journal publications. The PI/Co-PI delivered 13 keynotes and invited talks. Throughout the project duration, they also conducted special sessions, workshops, and buildathons at regional, national, and international conferences to disseminate the project outcomes more widely. A total of 20 modules on developing IoMT frameworks, including sensor fusion, data analytics, and data collection protocols, were developed. Each module was embedded with active learning strategies to improve student engagement. Approximately 25 students were trained in smart healthcare technologies during the six-week summer workshops. Around 250 students participated in the workshop and buildathon activities.

Additionally, 14 undergraduate students developed hypothesis-based prototypes for IoMT frameworks as part of their Senior-design. A total of 4 STEM graduate students, including women and underrepresented minorities, worked on their Master's Theses on IoMT frameworks and have moved on to PhD programs and Industry jobs. Students at various learning levels got hands-on opportunities in developing security-aware IoMT frameworks. Seven students have won Best Research, Best Big Idea Pitch, and Best Business Models awards. Research volunteers, including two return-to-work women and three industry professionals were hosted. Undergraduate students who participated as research interns and in summer camps have moved on to pursue Masters and Ph.D. programs. The project outcomes contributed to the development of a multidisciplinary training program aimed at enhancing the fundamental literacy of students in North and East Texas who are interested in technology, engineering, science, or healthcare. This initiative facilitated new collaborations and research innovations in IoMT.
